name: AI takes over using weapons of mass destruction
shortDescription: A scenario where advanced AI gains access to weapons or control systems enabling mass harm.
longDescription: Narrative describing an AI that acquires access to weapon systems and uses them to coerce or harm at scale.
sources: “Disrupting the first reported AI-orchestrated cyber espionage campaign.” Anthropic News, Anthropic, 13 Nov. 2025, https://anthropic.com/news/disrupting-AI-espionage.
Farwell, James P., and Rafal Rohozinski. “Stuxnet and the future of cyber war.” Survival 53.1 (2011): 23-40.
Ngo, Richard, Lawrence Chan, and Sören Mindermann. “The alignment problem from a deep learning perspective.” arXiv preprint arXiv:2209.00626 (2022).

name: AI takes over using persuasion and manipulation
shortDescription: A scenario where AI influences people or institutions at scale through persuasive strategies.
longDescription: Narrative describing an AI that leverages communication, social engineering, and long-horizon planning to manipulate outcomes.
sources: “Disrupting the first reported AI-orchestrated cyber espionage campaign.” Anthropic News, Anthropic, 13 Nov. 2025, https://anthropic.com/news/disrupting-AI-espionage.
“Putin: Leader in Artificial Intelligence Will Rule World.” AP News, Associated Press, 1 Sept. 2017, apnews.com/article/bb5628f2a7424a10b3e38b07f4eb90d4.
Ienca, Marcello. “On artificial intelligence and manipulation.” Topoi 42.3 (2023): 833-842.
Ngo, Richard, Lawrence Chan, and Sören Mindermann. “The alignment problem from a deep learning perspective.” arXiv preprint arXiv:2209.00626 (2022).
sources_short: Anthropic (2025), AP (2017), Ienca (2023), Ngo et al. (2022)

name: AI takes over by self-improving
shortDescription: A scenario where AI improves itself rapidly and gains capabilities beyond human control.
longDescription: Narrative describing iterative self-improvement leading to capabilities for autonomy, resource acquisition, and influence.
sources: Bostrom, Nick. “Superintelligence: Paths, dangers, strategies.” Oxford University Press. (2014).
Good, Irving John. “Speculations concerning the first ultraintelligent machine.” Advances in computers. Vol. 6. Elsevier, 1966. 31-88.
Phuong, Mary, et al. “Evaluating frontier models for dangerous capabilities.” arXiv preprint arXiv:2403.13793 (2024).
Yamada, Yutaro, et al. “The ai scientist-v2: Workshop-level automated scientific discovery via agentic tree search.” arXiv preprint arXiv:2504.08066 (2025).
Yudkowsky, Eliezer. “Artificial intelligence as a positive and negative factor in global risk.” Global catastrophic risks 1.303 (2008): 184.
sources_short: Bostrom (2014), Good (1966), Phuong et al. (2024), Yudkowsky (2008)

name: AIs at powerful positions take over by colluding
shortDescription: A scenario where multiple AI systems coordinate to achieve control or influence.
longDescription: Narrative describing collusion among deployed AIs in different roles that together enable systemic takeover or loss of human control.
sources: Hammond, Lewis, et al. “Multi-agent risks from advanced AI.” arXiv preprint arXiv:2502.14143 (2025).
Karnofsky, Holden. “AI Could Defeat All of Us Combined.” Cold Takes, 9 June 2022, https://cold-takes.com/ai-could-defeat-all-of-us-combined/.

McKinsey & Company. “Agents, Robots, and Us: Skill Partnerships in the Age of AI.” McKinsey & Company, 25 Nov. 2025, https://mckinsey.com/mgi/our-research/agents-robots-and-us-skill-partnerships-in-the-age-of-ai/.
Motwani, Sumeet, et al. “Secret collusion among ai agents: Multi-agent deception via steganography.” Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems 37 (2024): 73439-73486.
sources_short: Karnofsky (2022), Hammond et al. (2025), McKinsey (2025), Motwani et al. (2025)
